;;物流公司菜鸟在香港机场运营一个12层仓库。图片：Sam Tsang;
;

;物流公司菜鸟最近豁免住宅附加费，可加强香港的供应链管理，并通过帮助中国内地企业将产品推向跨境，推动全球电子商务经济学家表示，这更容易。

;

;但一位香港行业领袖兼航运委员会负责人表示，如果香港想成为跨国供应链管理中心，就需要更多精通全球采购和贸易合规的人才正如城市大亨冯国经向中国国家主席习近平建议的那样。

;

;香港付货人委员会主席林宣武表示，阿里巴巴集团物流部门此举南华早报的所有者菜鸟是一位“激进”人士，这得益于该运营商去年在该市机场开设了一个大型仓库。

;

;“菜鸟现在正在积极寻求更多商机来推广香港作为其电子商务基地，”林说。

;

;他补充说，该公司希望更多的人使用其系统，“这就是为什么它提供了这样的附加费豁免”。

;< p>;菜鸟上个月宣布，即日起，全市范围内的送货将免收住宅附加费——这意味着用户如果需要送货上门，将不会被收取额外费用。

;

;12-位于该市机场的多层仓库菜鸟智能网关占地 380,902 平方米（400 万平方英尺），配备了最新的数字技术。它于去年10月开始运营。

;

;商业大亨冯国经5月底在济南的一次会议上向习近平建议，该金融中心可以发展成为中型企业的供应链中心，

;

;随着菜鸟宣布豁免住宅附加费策略，香港供应链管理集团冯氏集团主席冯氏提出了这一前景。

;

;财政司司长陈茂波在二月份财政预算案讲话中表示，香港的目标是成为跨国供应链管理中心，符合内地制造企业将生产供应链延伸到海外的趋势。

;

;林说，香港实现目标的最大障碍是缺乏具有全球采购专业知识和其他国家贸易规则合规经验的人才。

;

;他补充说，问题是由中美地缘政治造成的紧张局势导致中国和香港的制造企业在过去五年将业务转移到东南亚国家，以避免美国政府施加的限制。

;

;“许多美国公司已收到美国的通知林说：“商务部要求他们的全球采购（业务）应该避开中国和香港，甚至他们的发票也不能在香港开具。”

;

;“香港应该培训更多全球供应人才连锁管理，让企业派人到海外。”

;
;;
;;大亨冯国经向习主席建议香港应致力于成为主要的国际供应链中心。照片：陈晓梅;
;
;

;林将人才短缺的部分原因归因于Covid-19大流行期间制造企业的增长放缓。

;

;Tang Hei-wai香港大学经济学教授表示，菜鸟的附加费豁免可以增加香港与内地之间的跨境和数字贸易。

;

;他补充说，这是转变城市的“重要组成部分”浸会大学会计、经济及金融系副教授麦瑞财表示，香港作为国际城市的地位可以使其成为重要的“测试基地” ”对于想要向海外扩张的内地物流公司来说。

;

;“如果菜鸟能够利用其在香港的经验[优化]在线购物和送货[运营]，那么它可以帮助在海外推广自己，”他

;

;麦预测，如果菜鸟仓库备有热门产品，海外买家可以通过香港更快地从中国最大的在线市场淘宝购买产品。

;;最后，新纳粹抗议者在墨尔本议会大厦外向纳粹致敬年。照片：EPA-EFE;
;

;专家警告说，在散布恐惧的移民恐慌运动的推动下，澳大利亚即将举行的联邦选举可能会成为一场关于阻止外国人入境的公投。但他们表示，政治言论与现实不符，进一步削减移民可能会危及经济。

;

;关于澳大利亚这个亚太地区受欢迎的移民目的地是否受到生活水平提高的打击的激烈争论上个月，在反对党领袖彼得·达顿(Peter Dutton)批评政府新联邦预算中计划的移民数字过高后，就开始让太多人进入该国。

;

;他指责移民住房短缺，造成道路拥堵和公共服务紧张，引发仇外情绪，并引发一场关于澳大利亚是否是种族主义国家的激烈全国辩论。

;
;;
;;去年，新纳粹抗议者在墨尔本议会大厦外行纳粹礼。一位顶级政治评论员最近公开表示澳大利亚是一个种族主义国家，遭到了右翼专家的强烈反对。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;预算的设计者、财长吉姆·查尔默斯 (Jim Chalmers) 在周三的新闻发布会上回应称，澳大利亚必须以负责任的方式管理其移民，认识到“通过加剧技能短缺并不能解决住房短缺或老年护理护士短缺问题”。

;

;移民专家表示，煽动性言论可能会阻止潜在的移民，但预测澳大利亚目前的移民情况澳大利亚移民部门前高级官员阿布尔·里兹维 (Abul Rizvi) 描述了当前的政治焦点移民问题是他 35 年观察国家政策以来所见过的“最激烈的”。

;

;他说这一切几乎证实了关于移民的辩论包含了实质内容和“雾里看花”的混合体充满仇外心理和利己主义的——将主导选举。

;

;“针对[国际]学生的政策肯定正在收紧，”里兹维说。 “从永久移民的角度来看，现任政府基本上是稳定的。从政治修辞的角度来看，一切都在改变。热度正在上升。”

;

;澳大利亚正在发生的事情也反映出移民、种族和分裂的更广泛趋势被其他国家的政客武器化，包括新西兰、美国、英国和爱尔兰周五举行了欧洲议会选举。

;

;瑞典学者 Ashok Swain 在为联合国准备的研究中表示，移民已成为“大多数移民接收国民粹主义激增的主要原因” 2019 年，基于移民对“本土文化”构成的威胁，将这些国家民族主义的兴起归因于反移民政治动员。

;
;;
;;反对党领袖彼得·达顿批评政府新联邦预算中计划的移民数字过高。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;这并不是达顿第一次利用种族和移民作为政治工具。此前，他曾在澳大利亚煽动人们对“非洲帮派”的恐惧，对“与中国的战争”发出警告，并有人无意中听到他开玩笑说太平洋岛国海平面上升。

;

;

;

;专家们很快就提出了达顿的移民主张。

;

;悉尼科技大学国际移民和难民法高级讲师萨拉·德姆 (Sara Dehm) 表示，他的分裂言论“忽视了澳大利亚移民制度的真正危机”。

;

;“这种移民恐慌助长了人为的‘我们和他们’分歧，并造成了移民危机的感觉，然后被用来证明对非公民采取更多移民控制和限制是合理的，”她在一份报告中表示。本月早些时候的评论。

;

;当顶级政治评论员劳拉·廷格尔公开表示澳大利亚是一个种族主义国家时，她遭到了右翼专家的强烈反对。但她立场坚定，认为仔细审查反对派领导人将住房危机归咎于移民的言论至关重要，因为此类言论可能威胁社会凝聚力。

;
;;
;;2019 年，澳大利亚墨尔本，在民族主义者和反种族主义示威者的集会和反集会上，骑警将抗议者分开。照片：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;澳大利亚联邦议会独立议员阿莱格拉·斯彭德 (Allegra Spender) 指责达顿提出虚假论点。

;

;“移民不是租金压力的驱动因素 - 这是历届地方、州和联邦政府失败的住房供应政策，以及我们向减少每套住房人口的转变，”她在周二的评论中表示。

;

;里兹维表示反对派的模糊的削减移民提案缺乏释放住房或降低房价的具体细节，有些甚至是相互矛盾的。

;

;达顿承诺在两年内将永久移民人数从 185,000 人削减至 140,000 人，却忽略了大多数人获得永久居留权的事实他说：“无论如何，140,000 人与过去 20 多年的平均水平相差并不远……所以（达顿）所说的并不算离谱，除了他所说的言辞之外。”围绕它，包括他所说的‘释放 100,000 个家庭’，”Rizvi 说。

;
;;
;;布里斯班昆士兰科技大学。澳大利亚政府在过去几个月削减了移民人数，包括国际学生的配额。图片来源：Shutterstock;
;
;

;此外，Rizvi 表示，政府在过去几个月中已经削减了移民人数，包括国际学生的配额。

;

;“我我认为他[达顿]有信心大多数选民不会对细节感兴趣。他们只会将生活中的所有问题归咎于移民。”他说。

;

;政府和反对派都意识到，减少移民，特别是技术移民，会适得其反。 Rizvi 说。

;

;达顿领导的自由党在 2022 年之前执政澳大利亚，实际上在疫情结束时增加了移民数量，增加了海外学生数量，提供无限的工作权利以及免费申请和特殊待遇。签证。现任政府一直延续这些措施，直到去年到期。

;

;宽松的政策导致签证制度被滥用和移民受到剥削，导致澳大利亚创下有史以来最高的净移民增长518,000人根据澳大利亚统计局 12 月发布的数据，截至 2023 年 6 月的一年中。

;

;周五，随着堪培拉修订了一项部长级指示，可能会驱逐更多有刑事犯罪的人，对移民的关注加剧。记录，即使他们与出生国没有联系并且深深扎根于澳大利亚。

;
;;
;;奥克兰皇后街上的行人。新西兰最新的人口普查显示其人口正在多样化。图片：Bloomberg;
;
;

;

;

;与邻国澳大利亚的骚乱相比，新西兰在移民问题上的动荡较少。然而，4月份，当地政府收紧了工作签证规定，理由是取消大流行边境限制后移民水平“不可持续”。

;

;惠灵顿还表示将审查移民政策，包括重新关注技术移民。但根据社会学家 Paul Spoonley 的说法，移民目前并不是新西兰的主要政治优先事项。

;

;他敦促新西兰在制定其政策时考虑移民以外的因素，例如生育率和地区人口概况。更广泛的人口政策。

;

;新西兰最新的人口普查显示，其人口正在老龄化，增长放缓，但也变得更加多样化，亚裔新西兰人和毛利人是增长最快的族裔群体。

;
;;
;;一名旅客在悉尼机场推着行李车。技术移民是澳大利亚的首要任务。图片：Bloomberg;
;
;

;Rizvi 表示，技术移民，特别是在健康、教育和建筑领域，是新西兰和澳大利亚的首要任务。

;

;墨尔本大学人口学教授 Peter McDonald 上个月对澳大利亚劳动力市场进行的分析显示，护士、教师、IT 工人和工程师是需求量最大的技术工人。

;

;上个月在预算中，堪培拉明确表示主要对“才华横溢的移民”感兴趣，甚至削减了一些计划，例如所谓的黄金签证，因为它们“带来了糟糕的经济成果”。

;

;虽然澳大利亚专注于技术移民里兹维表示，移民不太可能发生变化，堪培拉可能会对打工度假等临时签证进行小幅调整。但他预计围绕移民的政治言论将会持续下去。

;

;“事实上，你会发现反对党领袖[达顿]会批评政府没有引进足够的建筑商人，并说这就是为什么澳大利亚没有引进足够的建筑工人。”建造足够多的房子，”他说。

;;提供自动驾驶解决方案的Minieye技术已提交申请在香港公开。图片：讲义;
;

;由阿里巴巴集团控股有限公司首席执行官吴永明支持的中国自动驾驶公司迷你眼科技已提交在香港证券交易所上市的申请，成为最新的内地自动驾驶公司一家科技公司希望在香港交易所上市。

;

;该公司在 5 月 27 日提交招股说明书之前已经进行了至少 17 轮融资。据《国际金融评论》报道，该公司计划筹集 1.5 亿美元。该公司尚未透露目标估值，仅表示已超过上市时所需的 40 亿港元（5.12 亿美元）市值。

;

;吴 – 阿里巴巴联合创始人、所有者南华早报的 - 是该公司最引人注目的支持者之一。招股说明书显示，他在 2019 年转让了价值 3060 万元（420 万美元）的股份后，持有该公司 2.3% 的股份，此时距离他进行 450 万元天使投资已经四年了。

;
;< img src="https://cdn.i-scmp.com/sites/default/files/d8/images/canvas/2024/06/09/47e36f38-9619-40cd-9f41-361a043dbbce_1126e908.jpg" alt="" >;
;;Minieye 技术在 2023 年上海国际汽车工业展览会上的展示。照片：讲义;
;
;

;开始-up 的企业支持者包括北京四维管理、深圳泽一和中国国际金融等投资公司。

;

;由企业家刘国庆于 2014 年创立，刘国庆于 2014 年获得新加坡南洋理工大学计算机科学博士学位。 2013 年，Minieye 已为 29 家汽车制造商提供了高达 2 级的自动驾驶解决方案，这意味着该系统能够控制转向和加速，但需要驾驶员监控，类似于特斯拉的 Autopilot。

;

;去年，Minieye 的销量超过7.8亿智能驾驶解决方案。

;

;去年公司营收达4.76亿元，三年复合年增长率达64.9%。 2022年和2021年的收入分别为2.79亿元和1.75亿元。

;

;然而，该公司运营十年后仍未扭亏为盈。去年，该公司亏损1.39亿元人民币，比2022年和2021年分别亏损2.21亿元人民币和2.07亿元人民币有所改善。

;

;随着该公司准备上市，它一直在减少研究和投资。研发支出占收入比重。

;

;去年研发支出1.5亿元，比上年的1.39亿元增长近8%，占收入比重下降至31.5%。 2022年将增长49.9%。根据招股说明书，2021年研发支出为8220万元人民币，占收入的46.9%。

;

;事实证明，香港对内地自动驾驶公司来说是一个有吸引力的目的地寻求进入国际市场。 iMotion Automotive Technology 总部位于上海以西的苏州，是第一家于 12 月在香港交易所上市的中国自动驾驶公司。

;

;;习近平和埃马纽埃尔·马克龙在中国领导人最近访问中国期间合影法国。照片：彭博社;
;

;莫里斯·古尔多-蒙塔涅 (Maurice Gourdault-Montagne) 于 1978 年至 2019 年间担任法国外交官，曾担任驻日本、英国、德国和中国大使。他是前总统雅克·希拉克的高级外交顾问，也是总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙的阿联酋特使。此专访首次刊登于南华早报Plus。如需了解开放问题系列中的其他采访，请点击 。

;

;

;

;就我们正在经历的美国和中国在全球范围内的紧张局势以及太平洋上的地区性对抗，以及欧盟和中国之间由于各种原因而产生的紧张局势，以及地缘政治造成的紧张局势，这些都给我们带来了世界更多的裂痕和分裂。

;

;因此，这次访问是必要的，而且是在习主席上次访问欧洲五年后进行的。

;

;而且在这一背景下，这是对建国六十周年的重要提醒和庆祝。中法建交周年纪念日。

;

;庆祝活动并不完全是巧合，因为它是一个机会提醒我们，这种[建立关系]是在高度紧张的时期发生的出色地。那是冷战，那是越南战争。当时法国对阿尔及利亚的殖民统治刚刚结束。

;

;The idea, championed by the US, is to use this profit as a steady revenue stream to service a large loan of US$50 billion that could be raised on the market. Russia says any diversion of the profits from its frozen funds would amount to theft.

;

;Tapping profits from Russian assets has drawn concerns from some countries, but a US Treasury official said on Tuesday that the United States and its G7 partners were making progress.

;
;;
;;Macron and his wife Brigitte Macron, left, with Biden and his wife Jill Biden at the Presidential Elysee Palace in Paris, France on Saturday. Photo: AFP;
;
;

;Biden ended his trip to France by paying his respects at an American military cemetery that Donald Trump notably skipped when he was president, hoping his final stop on Sunday helped draw the stakes of the November election in stark relief.

;

;Before returning to the US, Biden honoured America's war dead at the Aisne-Marne American Cemetery about an hour outside Paris. He placed a wreath at the cemetery chapel before an expanse of white headstones marking the final resting place of more than 2,200 US soldiers who fought in World War I.

;

;It was a solemn end to five days in which Trump是一种不言而喻但不可避免的存在。表面上看，这次访问是为了纪念诺曼底登陆80周年，并庆祝美法结盟。 But during an election year when Trump has called into question fundamental understandings about America's global role, Biden has embraced his Republican predecessor – and would-be successor – as a latent foil.

;

;Every ode to the transatlantic partnership was a reminder that Trump could upend those relationships.每一次提到民主都与他的对手推翻总统选举的努力相对立。 The myriad exhortations to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia created a contrast with Trump's scepticism about providing US help.

;

;Biden's paeans to the struggle between democracy and autocracy drew plaudits in Europe, where the prospect of a return to Trump's turbulent reign has sparked no shortage of anxiety. But it remains to be seen how the message will resonate with American voters, as Biden's campaign struggles to connect the dire warnings the Democratic president so often delivers about his rival with people's daily concerns.

;
;;
;;Biden attends a wreath-laying ceremony at Aisne-Marne American Cemetery in Belleau, France on Sunday. Photo: AP;
;
;

;The visit to the cemetery served as a moment to underscore the contrast once more.

;

;“It's the same story,” Biden said 。 “美国出现了。美国出现阻止德国人。美国的出现是为了确保他们不会获胜。 And America shows up when we're needed just like our allies show for us.”

;

;During a 2018 trip to France, Trump skipped plans to go to the cemetery, a decision that the White House blamed on weather当时。然而，随后的报道称，特朗普告诉助手，他不想去，因为他认为死去的士兵是“傻瓜”和“失败者”。 Trump has denied the comments, although they were later corroborated by his chief of staff at the time, John Kelly.

;

;Trump's purported insults have become a regular feature of Biden's campaign speeches, including during an April rally in Scranton, Pennsylvania.

;

;“These soldiers were heroes, just as every American who has served this nation,” Biden said. “Believing otherwise, that alone is disqualifying for someone to seek this office.”

;

;Biden ignored a direct question about Trump at the cemetery but said it was important to visit the hallowed ground. “The idea that I would come to Normandy and not make the short trip here to pay tribute,” he added, his voice trailing off as if to express disbelief.

;

;Maura Sullivan, a former Marine officer who served on the American Battle Monuments Commission under President Barack Obama, said Biden's visit would “set the example, and do what a president should do.” Now an official with the New Hampshire Democratic Party, Sullivan said that “voters can draw their own conclusions” from that.

;

;Biden's trip was full of emotional moments, and the president grew heavy-eyed after meeting with Second World War veterans. A 21-gun salute cast eerie smoke over 9,388 white marble headstones at the Normandy American Cemetery.

;

;“This has been the most remarkable trip that I've ever made,” Biden said on Saturday night, his last in Paris before returning to the US.

;

;At Aisne-Marne, Biden said the trip “surprised me how much it awakened my sense of why it's so valuable to have these alliances.为什么它如此关键。 That's the way you stop wars, not start wars.”

;
;
;

;Biden's trip was also punctuated by the pomp of a state visit in Paris.

;

;Macron arranged a ceremony at the Arc du Triomphe, where four fighter jets flew overhead, and hosted a banquet at the Elysee presidential palace.

;

;“United we stand, divided we fall,” Macron said in toasting Biden. “Allied we are, and allied we will stay.”

;

;Overall, Biden's visit had a slower pace than other foreign trips.这位81岁的总统乘坐夜间航班抵达巴黎的第一天没有举行任何公开活动，也没有按照惯例与记者举行新闻发布会。 John Kirby, a national security spokesman, said that was necessary to prepare “in advance of the weighty engagements” during subsequent days.

;

;Still, it was a contrast to Macron's tendency to offer prestigious guests an intense schedule with a mix of official meetings, business talks, cultural events and private dinners at fancy restaurants.

;

;When the 46-year-old French leader hosted Chinese President Xi Jinping last month, the two-day agenda was crammed with activities including a trip to the Pyrenees Mountains near the border with Spain where Macron spent time as a child.

;

;Israeli forces pounded central Gaza anew on Sunday, a day after killing 274 Palestinians during a hostage rescue raid, and tanks advanced further into Rafah in an apparent bid to seal off part of the southern city, residents and Hamas media said.

;

;Palestinians remained in shock over Saturday's death toll, the worst over a 24-hour period of the Gaza war for months and including many women and children, Palestinian doctors said.

;

;In an update on Sunday, Gaza's health ministry said 274 Palestinians were killed – up from 210 it reported on Saturday – and 698 were injured when Israeli special force commandos stormed into the densely populated al-Nuseirat camp to rescue four hostages held since October by Hamas militants.

;

;Sixty-four of the dead were children and 57 were women, the Hamas-run Gaza government media office said on Sunday.

;
;;
;;Family and friends of the remaining hostages held in Gaza by Hamas launch a small blimp calling for their release in Tel Aviv, Israel on Sunday. Photo: AP;
;
;

;Israel's military said a special forces officer was killed in exchanges of fire with militants emerging from cover in residential blocks, and that it knew of “under 100” Palestinians killed, though not how many of them were fighters or civilians.

;

;Hamas' armed wing said on Sunday three Israeli hostages, including one with US citizenship, were killed during the raid, but provided no names. It released a video of what appeared to be corpses with censor bars obscuring their faces.

;

;A Hamas assertion on Saturday that some hostages had died was rejected as “a blatant lie” by the Israeli military.

;

;Gaza's health ministry said another 798 Palestinians were injured in the Israeli raid, and one of them, four-year-old Tawfiq Abu Youssef, was in critical condition when visited in hospital on Sunday by his father Raed.

;

;The boy was first thought to have died before he moved his hand slightly while in the arms of a relative rushing him to hospital – captured in a video that went viral on social media.

;

;“I had already dug his grave,” his father said, adding that most members of his extended family were among those killed in the raid.

;
;
;

;In central Gaza on Sunday, Israeli strikes on houses in the city of Deir al-Balah and in the nearby al-Bureij refugee camp killed three Palestinians in each location, while tanks shelled parts of al-Nuseirat and al-Maghazi camps, doctors said.

;

;The Israeli military said in a statement its forces were continuing operations east of al-Bureij and Deir al-Balah, killing a number of Palestinian gunmen and destroying militant infrastructure.

;

;Israel sent forces into Rafah in May in what it called a mission to wipe out Hamas' last intact combat units after eight months of war, in which Israeli forces have bombed much of the rest of Gaza to rubble while advancing against fierce resistance from militants embedded in crowded cities and built-up camps.

;

;Israeli tank forces have since seized Gaza's entire border strip with Egypt running through Rafah to the Mediterranean coast and invaded many districts of the city of 280,000 residents, prompting around one million displaced people who had been sheltering in Rafah to flee elsewhere.

;
;
;

;On Sunday, tanks advanced into two new districts in an apparent effort to complete the encirclement of the entire eastern side of Rafah, touching off clashes with dug-in Hamas-led armed groups, according to residents trapped in their homes.

;

;Palestinian doctors said an Israeli air strike on a house in Tel Al-Sultan in western Rafah killed two people.

;

;The Israeli military said troops of its 162nd division were raiding some districts of Rafah where they had located “numerous additional terror tunnel shafts, mortars, and [other] weapons” belonging to Palestinian Islamist militants.

;

;Hamas precipitated the war with a lightning cross-border attack into Israel last October 7, killing around 1,200 people and seizing more than 250 hostages, according to Israeli tallies. About half the hostages were freed during a brief November truce.

;

;Israel's ensuing air and ground war in Gaza has killed at least 37,084 Palestinians, the health ministry in the Hamas-run territory said in its Sunday update. The ministry says thousands more dead are feared buried under the rubble.

;
;;
;;A woman and child walk thorough debris in the aftermath of Israeli strikes in Nuseirat refugee camp, central Gaza on Sunday. Photo: Reuters;
;
;

;Attempts by the United States and regional countries to broker a deal that would release all remaining hostages in return for a ceasefire have repeatedly stumbled on Israeli and Hamas intransigence over terms for an end to the war.

;

;A humanitarian catastrophe has unfolded as the war has dragged on, with more than three-quarters of Gaza's 2.3 million population displaced, malnutrition widespread and basic infrastructure in ruins.

;

;Gaza's conflict has destabilised the wider Middle East, drawing in Hamas' main supporter Iran and its Lebanese ally Hezbollah, which has been clashing with Israel along its northern border for months, raising fears of all-out war.

;

;Concern about an escalation in Israeli-Hezbollah hostilities and a sharp decline in expectations of a Gaza ceasefire have weakened Israel's shekel currency by 3 per cent to 3.75 to the dollar since June 4.
